_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Clycol Chiller Presure Relief and System

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
tion of the plant to the west side of the property.  Headcounts were taken to assure all employees were out, with the exception of a small crew of 5 maintenance persons who were assisting the local response teams in identifying the issue.  Once the response teams were well in place these remaining employees joined the rest of our employees at the evacuation point.  The local response teams then took complete control of the situation, along with gathering input, knowledge, and assistance as necessary from our management staff during the emergency response.  Only after the building was determined safe were our employees allowed back into the facility.  Immediately following the incident the facility was toured and monitored throughout the night to assure no further issues arose.  The release completely gassed off on the roof and did not require any clean-up, removal, or transportation.

Emergency services were called around 8:30 pm and local emergency services responded.  The White Bear Lake Fire Department notified the Minnesota Duty Officer at 8:50pm, during the initial response to the release.  The National Response Center was notified of our release the night of the release, on August 13th at 10:27pm.  

The facility was fully evacuated following the release and no one was aloud to return until full assessment and response was completed to determine the plant safe.  The evacuation occurred on August 13th at 8:30pm and ended at 12:05am on August 14th.  There were no deaths involved in the release.  There were two employees, one delivery truck driver, and one responding police officer that experienced respiratory irritation from inhalation of the ammonia vapors.  During the evacuation, the two employees and truck driver were removed to fresh air.  None were unconscious.  The two employees and the truck driver were removed from the scene by ambulance and received medical care at Regions Hospital.  These three individuals were held overnight for observation purposes a

nd released to return to work the following day, on August 14th.  The Police officer cleaned up and drove himself to the hospital to be examined and was released that same evening, on August 13th, without being admitted.

Two employees from the adjacent Dairy Queen and one employee from the adjacent Shell gas station were evacuated.  Both facilities were down wind of the plant.

Preventative Action Taken ¿ The action taken to prevent a new occurrence is listed below:
1. Pressure relief valves were replaced.
2. Ammonia level float was replaced.
3. Control systems were inspected and were functioning properly other than the float that was corrected when the float was replaced.
4. Ammonia float and level inside chiller is inspected during rounds.
5. Upgrade glycol system holding tank capacity.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Our emergency response program consists of training for the associates, rapid communication, and mitigation.  Specific associates are trained and certified as emergency responders. All associates are trained in evacuation, hazard communication, and chemical safety.  Our emergency response plans are filed and reviewed by OSHA.  The general procedure is as follows:

1. Immediately notify the Emergency Response Team over the paging system or radio.
2. If the NH3 problem is deemed to be serious, then 9-9-1-1 (for the Fire Department) will be called by the Emergency Response Team.  
3. Immediately initiate plant evacuation procedures.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

It is the intent of the Morningstar division to become proficient in emergency response by training the workforce as an emergency response team.  The make up of the team and planned response will be under the review and direction of the Corporate Environmental and Safety Director.

The process safety management policy of Dean Foods is as follows: Identify, evaluate and continually improve on processes that affect the ability to prevent and mitigate the risk of release of acutely hazardous

materials at each facility. We will communicate effectively to management, effected employees and the community the necessary awareness and preparation for the response to any potential events based on the probability of the risk.  Next, we will integrate all potentially compatible safety requirements and guidelines that are expected and implied for use at all company facilities and that enhance the capability of this system.  Finally, it is our goal to maintain ongoing compliance of all PSM requirements.

Our company has an extensive safety audit program.  Each facility is audited annually.  The Corporate Safety Department performs the annual audit.  The audit scores are tied in with overall plant ratings.  Management is accountable for the facility rating.  Emergency response, evacuation, PSM, Hazard communication, etc. is all covered by the safety audit.  Each audit includes specific recommendations for correcting program deficiencies.

Dean Foods Company is a leading manufacturer and distributor of fresh milk and related dairy products, shelf-stable and refrigerated food and beverage products, frozen food products, coffee, and plastic containers. The Company's products are distributed throughout the United States and Puerto Rico

Kohler Mix Specialties of Minnesota, LLC a subsidiary of Morningstar Foods, LLC.  It is our corporate and company policy to provide every employee a safe and healthy workplace. Our corporate safety policy provides guidance for implementation, operation and review of the standards that govern the Ammonia Refrigeration Systems that use anhydrous ammonia or any other highly hazardous chemical that are defined by the threshold planning quantities of the Federal and/or State standard. This includes any of the operational facilities that manufacture, store and distribute product in the company. 

The personal health and safety of each employee is our first concern and top priority.  Management will provide a safe and healthy workplace to the greatest degree possible.  Our efforts for personal safety and health shall be in keeping with the highest standards.  To accomplish this, management will provide all reasonable safeguards to ensure safe working conditions.

The Kohler Mix Specialties of Minnesota, LLC facility is located in the City of White Bear Lake, Minnesota.  The facility employs approximately 155 full-time associates.  Our primary products include extended shelf life and aseptic dairy and non-dairy food products.  The refrigeration system is used for processing and cold storage of dairy food products. 

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The ammonia release occurred on August 13th around 8:15pm.  At that time the actual quantity of the release was unknown.  During the next four days we analyzed the systems, equipment, and incident involved during the August 13th release.  We involved several corporate and external consultants/contractors in both evaluating the issue and

determining the release quantity.

The weather conditions at the time of the release were evening clear skies, light wind from the Southeast, no precipitation, and cool ¿ 60s (F) in temperature.

The release of liquid ammonia was solely to the roof of the plant.  The gas, produced by the volatilization of the released liquid, was released to the air above the roof.  Some of this gas was drawn into the facility through ventilation units on the roof, and was eventually all discharged to the exterior through air exchange and exhausting of the plant.

The investigation identified that the ammonia level float failed and the 200-ton chiller filled with ammonia liquid.  Heated glycol entered the chiller shocking the system.  There was little headspace in the chiller vessel and the pressure rose quickly.  The ammonia gas had nowhere to expand and the result was the lifting of the relief valve dissipating the excess pressure.

251.7 pounds of Ammonia ¿anhydrous was released.  Release volume was provided and calculated by our refrigeration contractor American Industrial Refrigeration, with reference to Chemical Exposure Index Guide Dow Chemical, 2nd edition 1993.  The volume was determined by relief valve liquid quantity discharge possible during a 30 second release.  The formula consisted of the following inputs: ½ inch diameter relief valve, 37.2 pounds of Liquid Pressure, 150 pounds of gas pressure, and 30 second release.  The total was also crosschecked versus our relief spill puddle diameter to assure quantities were accurate.  Both calculations were within 10 pounds of each other, and we reported the higher of the two being 251.7.  

Ammonia vapor was identified outside the facility and 911 called.  Immediately following calling 911 the supervisor on duty gathered employees in the plant¿s lunchroom, which was a known safe area, and made the appropriate emergency contacts to other plant management.
